explanations: The particle は indicates that the noun before it is the topic of the sentence
です used here shows politeness to the listener
[Note] the particle は is read as わ
examples: 1) 私[わたし]は ケンワイ です。
1) I am KenWhy
2) 私[わたし]は 会社員[かいしゃいん] です。
2) I am a company employee

topic: Noun1 は Noun2 じゃ/では ありません
explanations: じゃ/では ありません is the negative form of です
じゃ ありません is used in spoken conversations
では ありません is used in formal speech and writing
[Note] the particle は in では is read as わ
examples: 1) サントさんは 学生[がくせい] じゃありません。
1) サントさんは 学生[がくせい] ではありません。
1) Mr Santos is not a student

topic: Noun1 は Noun2 ですか
explanations: The particle か at the end of the sentence indicates that it is a question
A question usually ends with a rising intonation
Replies to a yes/no question usaully begins with はい for agreement and いいえ for disagreement
An iterrogative question replaces
examples: 1) ミラーさんは アメリカじんですか。
1) Is Mr Miller an American?
1) ... はい，アメリカじんです。
1) ... Yes, he is an American
1) ... いいえ，アメリカじんじゃありません。
1) ... No, he is not an American

explanations: も is used when the same things applies to what was stated previously
examples: 1) ミラーさん は 先生[せんせい]です。グプタさん も 先生[せんせい]です
1) Mr Miller is a teacher. Mr Gupta is also a teacher

explanations: When a noun Noun1 modifies a following noun Noun2, の is used to connect the two nouns
Other uses include when Noun1 explains what Noun2 is about
And when Noun1 indicates who owns Noun2
examples: 1) ミラーさんは IMCの社員[しゃいん]です。
1) Mr Miller is an employee of IMC
2) これは コンピューターの 本[ほん]です。
2) This is a book on computers
3) これは 私[わたし]の 本[ほん]です。
3) This is my book

explanations: さん is added to the name or family name of another person to show respect
Do not add さん to your own name when speaking about yourself
ちゃん is added to small children names instead of さん to indicate familiarity
[Note] あなた which means 'you', is only used for someone who you are very familiar with
To be polite, use their name with さん whenever addressing someone or drop あなた entirely if it is implied
examples: 1) ミラーさんは IMCの社員[しゃいん]です。
1) Mr Miller is an employee of IMC

explanations: これ,それ and あれ are demonstratives and work as nouns
これ refers to something near the speaker
それ refers to something near the listener
あれ refers to something distant from both the speaker and the listener
examples: 1) それは 辞書[じしょ]ですか。
1) Is that a dictionary?
2) これは だれの 傘[かさ]ですか。
2) Whose umbrella is this?

topic: この Noun/その Noun/あの Noun
explanations: この,その and あの are the same as これ/それ/あれ but they modify nouns instead
examples: 1) この 本[ほん]は 私[わたし]のです。
1) This book is mine
2) あの かたは どなたですか。
2) Who is that person?

explanations: そう is often used to answer a yes/no question in the affirmative
違[ちが]います is often used to answer a yes/no question in the affirmative
examples: 1) それは 辞書[じしょ]ですか。
1) Is that a dictionary?
1) ... はい, そうです。
1) ... Yes, it is
2) それは ペンですか。
2) Is that a pen?
2) ... いいえ, 違[ちが]います。
2) ... No, it isn't

explanations: This is a question where the listener has to choose between two options for the answer
For this type of questions, it is usual to state the chosen options
examples: 1) これは 9 ですか, 7 ですか。
1) Is that a 9 or a 7?
1) It is a 9

explanations: の can be used instead of a noun , if it has already been mentioned
In the Noun1 の Noun2 format, this means that we can omit Noun2 to just Noun1 の
We can used の in this way for things but not for people
examples: 1) あれは だれの 鞄[かばん]ですか。
1) Whose bag is that?
1) ... さとうさんのです。
1) ... It is Ms Sato's bag
2) この 鞄[かばん]は あなたのですか。
2) Is this bag yours?
2) ... いいえ, 私[わたし]の じゃありません
2) ... No, it isn't mine

explanations: The prefix お is attached to words when the speaker is speaking politely
examples: 1) おみやげ
1) Souvenir
2) おさけ
2) Sake

explanations: This expression is used by the speaker to acknowledge new information he/she has just been given
It is pronounced with a falling intonation
examples: 1) この 傘[かさ]は あなたのですか。
1) Is this umbrella yours?
1) ... いいえ, 違[ちが]います。シュミットさんのです。
1) ... No it isn't. It is Mr Schmidt's
1) そうですか。
1) Oh, I see

explanations: ここ/そこ/あそこ refer to places
ここ refers to the place where the speaker is
そこ refers to the place where the listener is
あそこ refers to a place far from both speaker and listener
こちら/そちら/あちら are more polite alternatives for ここ/そこ/あそこ respectively

[Note] When the speaker regards the listener as in the same spot as themselves, that spot is regarded as ここ, そこ indicates a place slightly further away from where they both are, and あそこ somewhere even further away
Using this sentence pattern, you can state where a place, thing or person is
examples: 1) お手[て]洗[あら]いは あそこです。
1) The restroom is over there
2) 電[で]話[んわ]は 2階[かい]です。
2) The telephone is on the second floor
3) 山田[やまだ]さんは 事[じ]務[む]所[しょ]です。
3) Mr Yamada is in his office

explanations: どこ is used for asking 'Where?' and どちら for 'Which direction?'
どちら can also be used to ask 'Where?' as a more polite form of どこ
どこ/どちら are also used to ask the name of the country/company/school/organisation to which someone belongs
examples: 1) お手[て]洗[あら]いは どこうですか。
1) Where is the restroom
1) ... あそこです。
1) ... It's over there
2) エレベーターは どちらですか。
2) Where is the elevator
2) ... あちらです。
2) ... It's in that direction / It's over there
3) 国[くに]は どこですか。
3) Which country are you from?
4) 会社[かいしゃ]は どちらですか。
4) Which company do you work for?

explanations: This sentence pattern means that the product was made in the stated country
We also use どこ to ask the country/company of origin of a product
examples: 1) これは どこの コンピューターですか。
1) Where is this computer made?
1) ... 日[に]本[ほん]の コンピューターです。
1) ... It's made in Japan
1) ... IMCの コンピューターです。
1) ... It's made by the IMC company

topic: 今[いま] 時[じ] 分[ふん/ぷん] です
explanations: To express time, the counter suffixes 時[じ](o'clock) and 分[ふん/ぶん](minutes) are placed after the numbers
分 is read ふん after 2,5,7 or 9 and ぷん after 1,3,4,6,8 or 10
1,6,8 and 10 are read as いっ,ろっ,はっ,じゅっ(or じっ) before ぷん
To ask the time, なん is placed in front of じ or ぷん
examples: 1) 今[いま] 何[なん]時[じ]ですか。
1) What time is it now?

topic: Verb ます/ Verb ません/ Verb ました/ Verb ませんでした
explanations: Verb ます and its other forms works as predicates and shows respect to the listener
ます form is used when affirming something that is either habitual or in the present/future
ません form is used when denying something that is either habitual or in the present/future
ました form is used when affirming something that is in the past
ませんでした form is used when affirming something that is in the past
examples: 1) 毎[まい]朝[あさ] 6時[じ] 起[お]きます。
1) I wake up at 6 every morning
2) 明日[あひた] 6時[じ] 起[お]きます。
2) I'm going to get up at 6 tomorrow
3) 今朝[けさ] 6時[じ] 起[お]きました。
3) I woke up at 6 this morning

explanations: The particle に is appended to a time noun to indicate the time of occurrence of an action
[Note] に should only be used for time nouns that include numbers such as 時[じ] and 分[ふん/ぶん]
[Note] に can be optionally used for the following nouns: ~ようび, あさ, ひる, ばん, よる
examples: 1) 6時[じ]半[はん]に 起[お]きます。
1) I wake up at 6:30
2) 7月[がつ]2日[か]に 日[に]本[ほん]へ 来[き]ました。
2) I came to Japan on the 2nd of July
3) 日曜日[にちようび]に 奈良[なら]へ いきます。
3) I am going to Nara on Sunday

topic: Noun1 から Noun2 まで
explanations: から indicates a starting time or place, and まで indicates the finishing time or place
から and まで can be used separately and are not always used together
To indicate the starting or finishing time/date of a noun introduced as a topic, デスan be added after ~から or ~まで
examples: 1) 9時[じ]から 5時[じ]まで 勉[べん]強[きょう]します。
1) I study from 9 to 5
2) 大[おお]阪[さか]から 東[とう]京[きょう]まで 9時[じ]間[かん] かかります。
2) It takes 3 hours from Osaka to Tokyo
3) 9時[じ]から 働[はたら]きます。
3) I start work at 9
4) 銀行[ぎんこう]は 9時[じ]から 3時[じ]までです。
4) The bank is open from 9 to 3
5) 昼休[ひるやす]みは 12時[じ]からです。
5) Lunchtime starts at 12

explanations: The particle と connects two nouns in coordinate relation
examples: 1) 銀行[ぎんこう]は 休[やす]みは 土[ど]曜日[ようび]と 日[にち]曜日[ようび]です。
1) The bank is closed on Saturdays and Sundays

explanations: The particle ね is attached to the end of a sentence and is used to elicit agreement from the listener
Or to check that the listener has understood, or emphasize something to the listener
examples: 1) 毎[まい]日[にち] 10時[じ]まで 勉[べん]強[きょう]します。
1) I study till 10 every day
1) ... 大[たい]変[へん]ですね。
1) ... That's tough, isn't it
2) 山田[やまだ]さんの 電[でん]話[わ]番[ばん]号[ごう]は 871の 6813 です。
2) Mr Yamada's telephone number is 871-6813

topic: place へ 行[い]きます/来[き]ます/帰[かえ]ります
explanations: When a verb indicates movement to a certain place, the particle へ is put after the place noun to show the direction fo the move
[Note] the particle へ is read as え
examples: 1) 京[きょう]都[と]へ 行[い]きます。
1) I'm going to Kyoto
2) 日[に]本[ほん]へ 来[き]ました。
2) I came to Japan
3) 家[うち]へ 帰[かえり]ます。
3) I'm going home

topic: どこ(へ)も 行きません/行きませんでした
explanations: When you want to deny everything covered by an interrogative, you attach the particle も and put ther verb in its negative form
[Note] The particle へ here is optional
examples: 1) どこ(へ)も 行[い]きません。
1) I'm not going anywhere
2) 何[なに]も 食[た]べません。
2) I'm not going to eat anything
3) だれも 行[き]ませんでした。
3) Nobody came

topic: vehicle で 行[い]きます/来[き]ます/帰[かえ]ります
explanations: The particle で indicates a means or a method
Attach it after a vehicle noun and use it together with movement verb to indicate means of transport
For walking, speaker uses the expression 歩[ある]いて. In this case で is not used
examples: 1) 電[でん]車[しゃ]で 行[い]きます。
1) I'm going by train
2) タクシーで 来[き]ました。
2) I came by Taxi
3) 駅[えき]から 歩[ある]いて 帰[かえ]りました。
3) I walked home from the station

explanations: When talking about doing something with a person/animal, the person/animal is marked with particle と
If doing something by oneself, the expression 一人で．In this case, the particle と is not used
examples: 1) 家[か]族[ぞく]と 日[に]本[ほん]へ 来[き]ました。
1) I came to Japan with my family
2) 一人[ひとり]で 東[とう]京[きょう]へ 行[い]きます。
2) I'm going to Tokyo on my own

explanations: Use いつ to ask when something happened or will happen
[Note] We do not use the に particle after いつ
examples: 1) いつ 日[に]本[ほん]へ 来[き]ましたか。
1) When did you come to Japan?
1) ... 3月[がつ]25日[にち]に 来[き]ました。
1) ... I came on 25th March

explanations: The particle よ is placed at the end of the sentence to emphasize information that the listener does not know
It can also be used to show that the speaker is giving their judgement assertively
examples: 1) 北海道[ほっかいどう]に 馬[うま]が たくさん いますよ。
1) There are a lot of horses in Hokkaido, you know
2) マリヤさん このアイスクリーム おいしいですよ。
2) Maria, this ice-cream is delicious, you know

explanations: そうですね is used to express sympathy or agreement with the speaker
It is similar to そうですか, but while that is used to acknowledge new information, そうですね is used to show sympathy or agree with something the speaker already knew
examples: 1) 明日[あした]は 日曜日[にちようび]ですね。
1) It's Sunday tomorrow, isn't it?
2) ... あ, そうですね。
2) ... Oh, so it is

explanations: The particle を is used to indicate the direct object of a transitive verb
examples: 1) ジュース を 飲[の]みます。
1) I drink juice

explanations: A wide range of nouns are used as object of the verb します, which means that the action denoted by the noun is performed.
examples: 1) サッカー を します。
1) To play soccer
2) 会議[かいぎ] を します。
2) To hold a meeting
3) 宿題[しゅくだい] を します。
3) To do homework

topic: 何[なに] を しますか
explanations: To ask about someone's actions
examples: 1) 月曜日[げつようび] 何[なに] を しますか。
1) What will you be doing on Monday?
1) ... 京都[きょうと] へ 行[い]きます。
1) ... I'll be going to Kyoto
2) 昨日[きのう] 何[なに] を しましたか。
2) What did you do yesterday
2) ... サッカー を しました。
2) ... I played soccer

topic: 何: なん vs なに
explanations: Both なん and なに mean 'what'
We use なん when it precedes a word whose first sound is either in the た，だ or な row, or when using it with a counting suffix
In other cases, we use なに
[Note] なんで is used for asking 'Why' or 'How', なにで can be used when to only ask for 'How'
examples: 1) それは 何[なん]ですか。
1) What's that?
2) 何[なん]の 本[ほん]ですか。
2) What's that book about?
3) 寝[ね]る 前[まえ]に 何[なん]と 言[い]いますか。
3) What do you say before going to bed?
4) テレーザちゃんは 何[なん]歳[さい]ですか。
4) How old is Teresa?

explanations: The particle で, when added after a noun denoting a place, indicates the occurrence of an action at that place
examples: 1) 駅[えき]で 新聞[しんぶん]を 買[か]います。
1) I'm going to buy a newspaper at the station

explanations: This expression is used when the speaker wants to invite someone to do something
examples: 1) 一緒[いっしょ]に 京都[きょうと]へ いきませんか。
1) Would you like to go to Kyoto with us?
1) ... ええ，いいですね。
1) ... Yes, that's a nice idea

explanations: This expression is used when the speaker is inviting someone to do something
It can also be used when responding positively to an invitation
[Note] Verb ませんか and Verb ましょう are used to invite someone to do something but Verb ませんか shows that the speaker gives more consideration to what the listener might want
examples: 1) ちょっと 休[やす]みましょう。
1) Let's take a break
2) 一緒[いっしょ]に 昼[ひる]ご飯[はん]を 食[た]べましょう。
2) Let's have lunch together
2) ... ええ，食[た]べましょう。
2) ... Yes, lets do that

explanations: ~か as a response indicates that the listener has accepted some new information
It is used in the same way as そうですか
examples: 1) 日曜日[にちようび] 京都[きょうと]へ 行[い]きました。
1) I went to Kyoto on Sunday
1) ... 京都[きょうと]ですか。いいですね。
1) ... Kyoto,eh? Great!

explanations: The particle で indicates a method or a means used for an action.
examples: 1) はしで 食[た]べます。
1) I eat with chopsticks
2) 日本語[にほんご]で レポートを 書[か]きます。
2) I'm going to write the report in Japanese

topic: Word/Sentence は ~語[ご]で 何[なん]ですか。
explanations: This question is used to ask how to say a word or a sentence in another language
examples: 1) ありがとう は 英語[えいご]で 何[なん]でえすか。
1) What's 'Arigato' in English?
1) ... Thank you です。
1) ... It's 'Thank you'
2) Thank you は 日本語[にほんご]で  何[なん]ですか。
2) What's 'Thank you' in Japanese?
2) ... ありがとう です。
2) ... It's 'Arigato'

topic: Person に Noun を あげます
explanations: Verbs like あげます, かします and おしえます indicate imparting things or information, so they must be used with a noun saying to whom those things on information is imparted
The particle に is used to denote the recipient
The particle を is used to denote the object
examples: 1) 私[わたし]は 木村[きむら]さんに 花[はな]を あげました。
1) I gave Ms Kimura some flowers
2) 私[わたし]は イーさんに 本[ほん]を 貸[か]しました。
2) I lent Ms Lee a book
3) 私[わたし]は 山田[やまだ]さんに 英語[えいご]を 教[おし]えます。
3) I teach Mr Yamada english

topic: Person に Noun を もらいます
explanations: Verbs like もらいます，かります and ならいます indicate receiving things or information, so they are used with a noun indicating the person from whom those things or information are received
The particle に is used to denote the recipient
The particle を is used to denote the object
examples: 1) 私[わたし]は 山田[やまだ]さんに 花[はな]を もらいました。
1) I received some flowers from Mr Yamada
2) 私[わたし]は カリナさんに CDを 借[か]りました。
2) I borrowed a CD from Karina
3) 私[わたし]は ワンさんに 中国語[ちゅうごくご]を 習[なら]います。
3) I'm learning Chinese from Mr Wang

explanations: もう means 'already' and is used with Verbました to indicate that an action has been completed
The answer to the question もう Verbましたか as to whether an action has been completed is はい，もう Verbました if affirmative
If negative, we use いいえ，Verbて いません, this means that something has not been completed in the present
[Note] we do not use いいえ，Verbませんでした as that means that something was not done in the past
examples: 1) もう 荷物[にもつ]を 送[おく]りましたか。
1) Have you sent the baggage yet?
2) ... はい，(もう) 送[おく]りました。
2) ... Yes, I have sent it
3) ... いいえ, まだ 送[おく]っていません。
3) ... No, I haven't sent it yet．
4) ... いいえ, まだです。
4) ... No, not yet．

explanations: Particles are often omitted in informal speech when the relationship between the parts of the speech before and after them are obvious
examples: 1) この スプーン(は)，すてきですね。
1) This is a lovely sppon, isn't it?
2) コーヒー(を)，もう 一杯[いっぱい] いかがですか。
2) Would you like another cup of coffee?

explanations: Adjectives are used as predicated, and in sentences like Noun は Adj です they indicate the state of a noun or are used to modify a noun
They are divided into 2 groups, い-adjs and な-adjs

topic: Noun は な-adj です
explanations: Adjective sentences that are non-past and affirmative end in です, which shows politeness towards the listener
な-adjs drop their な when added before です
examples: 1) ワット先生[せんせい]は 親切[しんせつ]です。
1) Mr Watt is kind

topic: Noun は い-adj です
explanations: Adjective sentences that are non-past and affirmative end in です, which shows politeness towards the listener
い-adjs retain their い when added before です
examples: 1) 富士山[ふじさん]は 高[たか]いです。
1) Mt Fuji is high

topic: Noun は な-adj じゃ/では ありません
explanations: The non-past negative form of a な-adj is formed by dropping the な and attaching じゃ/では ありません to it
examples: 1) あそこは 静[しず]か じゃありません。
1) It's not quiet here

topic: Noun は い-adj ~くないいです
explanations: The non-past negative form of a い-adj is formed by dropping the final い and attaching じゃ/では ありません to it
[Note] The negative for いいです is よくないです
examples: 1) この 本[ほん]は おもしろくないです。
1) This book is not interesting

explanations: When an adjective is used to modify a noun, its is placed in front of the noun
な-adjs have a な before the noun
examples: 1) ワット先生[せんせい]は 親切[しんせつ]な 先生[せんせい]です。
1) Mr Watt is a considerate teacher

explanations: When an adjective is used to modify a noun, its is placed in front of the noun
examples: 1) 富士山[ふじさん]は 高[たか]い 山[やま]です。
1) Mt Fuji is a high mountain

explanations: が connects two sentences in an antithetical relationship.
When these are adjective clauses with the same subject, if the initial clause is positive, the other will be negative and vice versa
examples: 1) 日本[にほん]の 食[た]べ物[もの]は 美味[おい]しいですが, 高[たか]いです。
1) Japanese food is delicious but expensive

explanations: とても and あまり are both adverbs of degree, both come before the adjectives they modify
とても is used in affirmative sentences and mean 'very'
あまり is used negatively and means 'not very'
[Note] When あまり is used, the negative form of the adjective must be used
examples: 1) ペキンは とても 寒[さむ]いです。
1) Beijing is very cold
2) これは とても 有名[ゆうめい]な 映画[えいが]です。
2) This is a very famous movie
3) シャンハイは あまり 寒[さむ]くないです。
3) Shanghai is not very cold
4) さくら大学[だいがく]は あまり 有名[ゆうめい]な 大学[だいがく]じゃありません。
4) Sakura University is not a very famous university

explanations: This question 'Nounは どうですか' is used to inquire about someone's impression, opinion or feeling about a thing, place, person, etc that they experienced
examples: 1) 日本[にほん]の 生活[せいかつ]は どうですか。
1) How do you find life in Japan?
1) ... 楽[たの]しいです。
1) ... It's fun

explanations: The objects of some verbs and adjectives are marked with が
examples: 1) 私[わたし]は イタリア料理[りょうり]が 好[す]きです。
1) I like Italian food.
2) 私[わたし]は 日本語[にほんご]が わかります。
2) I understand Japanese
3) 私[わたし]は 車[くるま]が あります。
3) I have a car

explanations: This expression means'What kind of'
examples: 1) どんな スポーツが 好[す]きですか。
1) What kind of sports do you like?
1) ... サッカーが 好[す]きですか。
1) ... I like soccer

topic: Adverbs of degree: よく/だいたい/少[すこ]し/あまり/全然[ぜんぜん]
explanations: These adverbs are placed before verbs to convey their degree
よく is used affirmatively and means 'greatly'
だいたい is used affirmatively and means 'generally'
少[すこ]し is used affirmatively and means 'a little'
あまり is used negatively and means 'not very'
全然[ぜんぜん] is used negatively and means 'not at all'
[Note] When あまり or 全然[ぜんぜん] is used, the negative form of the verb must be used
examples: 1) 英語[えいご]が よく わかります。
1) I understand English well
2) 英語[えいご]が だいたい わかります。
2) I generally understand English
3) 英語[えいご]が 少[すこ]し わかります。
3) I understand English a little
4) 英語[えいご]が あまり わかりません。
4) I don't understand English very well
5) 英語[えいご]が 全然[ぜんぜん] わかりません。
5) I don't understand English at all

topic: Adverbs of Quantity: たくさん/少[すこ]し/あまり/全然[ぜんぜん]
explanations: These adverbs are placed before verbs to convey their quantity
たくさん is used affirmatively and means 'a lot'
少[すこ]し is used affirmatively and means 'a little'
あまり is used negatively and means 'not much'
全然[ぜんぜん] is used negatively and means 'not at all'
[Note] When あまり or 全然[ぜんぜん] is used, the negative form of the verb must be used
examples: 1) お金[かね]が たくさん あります。
1) I have a lot of money
2) お金[かね]が 少[すこ]し あります。
2) I have a little bit of money
3) お金[かね]が あまり ありません。
3) I don't have a lot of money
4) お金[かね]が 全然[ぜんぜん] ありません。
4) I don't have any money

topic: 少[すこ]し/あまり/全然[ぜんぜん] Adj
explanations: 少[すこ]し/あまり/全然[ぜんぜん] can be used on adjectives as well
examples: 1) ここは 少[すこ]し 寒[さむ]いです。
1) It's a little cold here
2) あの 映画[えいが]は おもしろくないです。
2) That film is not at all interesting

explanations: A statement before から gives the reason for a statement after it
[Note] It is also possible to state something and add the reason after it by adding ~から
examples: 1) 時間[じかん]が ありませんから, 新聞[しんぶん]を 読[よ]みません。
1) I don't read newspapers because I don't have time
2) 毎朝[まいあさ] 新聞[しんぶん]を 読[よ]みまか。
2) Do you read the newspapers every morning?
2) ... いいえ，読[よ]みません。時間[じかん]が ありませんから。
2) ... No I don't．I don't have time.

explanations: The interrogative どうして is used to ask the reason for something
から is placed at the end of the reply giving the reason
The quesiton どうしてですか is used to ask the reason for something the other person already said, instead of repeating it
examples: 1) どうして 朝[あさ] 新聞[しんぶん]を 読[よ]みませんか。
1) Why do you not read the newspaper in the morning?
1) ... 時間[じかん]が ありませんから。
1) ... Because I don't have time.
2) 今日[きょ]は 早[はや]く 帰[かえ]ります。
2) I'm going home early today
2) ... どうしてですか。
2) 子[こ]どもの 誕生日[たんじょうび]ですから。
2) Because it's my child's birthday

topic: Noun が あります/います
explanations: あります/います indicate that something/someone exists
あります is used for a inanimate subjects such as plants or furniture
います is used for a animate subjects such as humans or animals
The particle が is used to denote the subject
examples: 1) コンピューターガ あります。
1) There is a computer
2) 桜[さくら]が あります。
2) There are cherry trees
3) 男[おとこ]の 人[ひと]が います。
3) There is a man
4) 犬[いぬ]が あります。
4) There is a dog

topic: Place に Noun が あります/います
explanations: The particle に is used to mark the place where the subject is at
We can use なに in place of the noun when asking what is present
We can use だれ in place of the noun when asking who is present
examples: 1) 私[わたし]の 部屋[へや]に 机[つくえ]が あります。
1) There is a desk in my room
2) 地下[ちか]に 何[なに]か ありますか。
2) What's in the basement?
2) ... レストランが あります。
2) ... There's a restaurant
3) 受付[うけつけ]に だれが いますか。
3) Who's at the reception desk?
3) ... 木村[きむら]さんが います。
3) ... Ms Kimura

topic: Noun は Place に あります/います
explanations: In this expression, the noun is treated as the sentence topic talks about its existence
The particle は is used to indicate the topic sentence and the noun is placed at the head of the sentence
In this case, the noun must be something both speaker and listener are aware of
examples: 1) 東京[とうきょう]デイズニーランドは 千葉県[ちばけん]に あります。
1) Tokyo Disneyland is in Chiba prefecture
2) ミラーさんは どこに いますか。
2) Where is Mr Miller?
2) ... 事務所[じむしょ]に います。
2) ... He's in the office

explanations: This expressions shows a positional relationship of Noun2 with Noun1
[Note] The particle で can be attached after Noun1 の Noun2 to indicate the location of an action
examples: 1) 机[つくえ]の 上[うえ]に 写真[しゃしん]が あります。
1) On the top of the desk, there is a phottograph
2) 郵便局[ゆうびんきょく]は 銀行[ぎんこう]の 隣[となり]に あります。
2) The post office is next to the bank
3) 本屋[ほんや]は 花屋[はなや]と スーパーの 間[あいだ]に あります。
3) The bookshop is in between the bookshop and the florist
4) 駅[えき]の 近[ちか]くで 友達[ともだち]に 会[あ]いました。
4) Near the train station, I met a friend

explanations: The particle と is used to connect nouns when going through a full list of nouns
The particle や is used when only a few items of the list of nouns are stated
など is sometimes added after the last noun to make it clear that the speaker has not mentioned all the nouns that could be in the list
examples: 1) 箱[はこ]の 中[なか]に 手紙[てがみ]や 写真[しゃしん]が あります。
1) The are some letters, photographs and other items in the box
2) 箱[はこ]の 中[なか]に 手紙[てがみ]や 写真[しゃしん]などが あります。
2) The are some letters, photographs and other items in the box

explanations: The words ひとつ，ふたつ，... とお are used to count things up to 10
From 11 and above, the numbers themselves are used when counting things
Different counter suffixes are used depending on what is counted
examples: 01) ~人[にん] People except for one and two
02) ~台[だい] Machines and vehicles
03) ~枚[まい] Thin, flat things
04) ~回[かい] Frequency, number of time
05) ~分[ふん/ぷん] Minutes
06) ~時間[じかん] Hours
07) ~日[にち] Days
08) ~週間[しゅうかん] Weeks
09) ~か月[げつ] Months
10) ~年[ねん] Years

explanations: Quantifiers are usually put straight after the noun + perticle that determines the type of quantifier
However, this is not always not the case with length of time
examples: 1) りんごを 四[よっ]つ 買[か]いました。
1) I bought four apples
2) 外国人[がいこくじん]の 学生[がくせい]が 二人[ふたり] います。
2) There are two foreign students
3) 国[くに]で 二[に]か月[げつ] 日本語[にほんご]を 勉強[べんきょう]しました。
3) I studied Japanese for two months in my home country

explanations: いくつ is used when asking how many there are of the items counted
examples: 1) みかんを いくつ 買[か]いましたか。
1) How many mandarin oranges did you buy?
1) ... 八[やっ]つ 買[か]いました。
1) ... I bought eight

explanations: なん + counter suffix is used when asking how many there are of things with a counter suffix
examples: 1) この 会社[かいしゃ]に 外国人[がいこくじん]が 何人[なんにん] いますか。
1) How many foreign people are there in this company?
1) ... 五人[ごにん] います。
1) ... There are five
2) 毎晩[まいばん] 何時間[なんじかん] 日本語[にほんご]を 勉強[べんきょう]しました。
2) How many hours do you study Japanese every night?
2) ... 二時間[にじかん] 勉強[べんきょう]します。
2) ... I study for two hours

explanations: どのくらい is used to ask the length of time something takes
examples: 1) どのくらい 日本語[にほんご]を 勉強[べんきょう]しましたか。
1) How long did you study Japanese for?
1) ... 三年[さんねん] 勉強[べんきょう]しました。
1) ... I studied it for three years
2) 大阪[おおさか]から 東京[とうきょう]まで どのくらい かかりますか。
2) How long does it take from Osaka to Tokyo?
2) ... 新幹線[しんかんせん]で 二時間半[にじかんはん] かかります。
2) ... It takes two and a half hours by Shinkansen

explanations: ぐらい is added after quantifiers to mean 'about'
examples: 1) 学校[がっこう]に 先生[せんせい]が 三十人[さんじゅうにん]ぐらい います。
1) There are thirty teachers at our school
2) 十五分[じゅうごふん]ぐらい かかります。
2) It takes about fifteen minutes

topic: Quantifier(Time period)に 回[かい] Verb
explanations: This expression indicates frequency
examples: 1) 一[いっ]か月[げつ]に 二回[にかい] 映画[えいが]を 見[み]ます。
1) I go to see a film about twice a month

topic: Quantifier だけ / Noun だけ
explanations: だけ means 'only'. It is added after quantifiers or nouns to indicate that there is no more or nothing else
examples: 1) パワー電気[でんき]に 外国人[がいこくじん]の 社員[しゃいん]が 一人[ひとり]だけ います。
1) There is only one foreign employee at Power Electric
2) 休[やす]みは 日曜日[にちようび]だけです。
2) Sunday is my only day off
